subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Utter/Ado
msgSnippet: ... I would think there should be just two differences between British and American English in QS: 1. Americans will use Ah where a British speaker would use
messageBody:
Moira O'Brien wrote:
>
>
> Paige
>
> I agree wholeheartedly with all that you say in this post.
>
> I haev little or no hesitancy as to which from of TH to use in writing
> or typing (I now type quite comfortably in Jerome font having labelled
> my keyboard for easy learing purposes).
>
> I actually get confused between WOOL and OOZE when writing and would
> never make a reading mistake as it is almost always clear from context
> which pronounciation I should use.
>
> I always use WH when relevant as it certainly aids reading, and I do
> distinguish WH from W in speech.
>
> I have already commented on the AH AWL OX which I distinguish.
>
> I certainly "think" the L in calm etc and would find it strange not to
> use it even though in lazy speech I probably ignore it.
>
> Lloch and Llan, I have never used and outside of Welsh names, I dont
> think I ever will.
>
> I have not found any great difficutly reading the news except that I
> have to think in an American accent to understand quickly! The main
> problem I have found is the loss of Utter especially from the begining
> of words. Since dropping Utter from the Utter + Roe combination, I have
> found reading has slowed significantly.
>
> I have anotated one of the news stories and will post my comments when I
> can find a few moments.
>

I would think there should be just two differences between British and
American English in QS:

1. Americans will use Ah where a British speaker would use On or Awl.
However, I have taken some care that the most common words do not merge
the Awl On Ah letters. With less common words, such as "bomb," the Ah
letter appears where the On letter should. I am hoping to change a great
many of these words in the near future.

2. Where Americans use Ash for words like "bath," British speakers use
Ah. This difference cannot be helped.

That means that #2 is the only difference between British and American
English in QS. If I am right, then the differences between the two
dialects appears very small in QS, which means we can communicate more
easily. At the same time, QS remains natural to use for any person in
all dialects.

The other differences you speak of, such as pronouncing the "l" in
"calm," or the "h" in "what," seem to appear in both American and
British English. Whether or not one uses these letters depends not on
what side of the Atlantic you were born.

I have changed the way the NURSE (or Utter) sound appears in the news.
You should now see this as the ligature Earth. There was a small problem
with the conversion in which case this ligature completely disappared;
likewise, there was a small problem in which Air completely disappeared.
I just fixed both problems.

Oh, one last point. I guess the new names you are confused by are the
names in all capitals, like NURSE? These aren't the names of letters,
but the names of the sounds represented by lexical sets. Yes, it's
absurdly confusing. But email doesn't allow us to represent QS easily;
and then when I tried to use IPA for the sound, that came out garbled;
so then I needed to use Sampa, yet another way to express a sound--and
in short, trying to talk about the specific sounds of QS on this mailing
list is one big mess, and I need to address that issue right now in
another email with the technical email group.

Paul
